reasoning: The critique targets the paper’s “strongest-link / multiple routes” rebuttal (counterargument #7), arguing that routes are coupled by a shared, compute-heavy validation step, so route diversity doesn’t evade compute bottlenecks. This is relevant but not core to the paper’s overall case (which offers many other reasons to expect higher substitutability / weaker bottlenecks), so centrality is moderate-low. The point substantially weakens that particular argument: even if idea-generation is cheap, discriminating among proposals and establishing frontier generalization plausibly requires large training/eval runs. However it doesn’t fully refute the paper’s broader thesis, and it overstates somewhat (“nearly all routes”) because some progress/selection may be possible via smaller-scale experiments, theory, or transfer/extrapolation—exactly the kind of escape the paper gestures at. The critique is clear, focused, and has little extraneous content.
title: Route diversity collapses when all paths share the same compute-intensive validation bottleneck
